message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the pain and its aggravation indicates that the patient may have patellofemoral pain syndrome. Pain upon compression of the patella while the patient performs flexion and extension of the leg is a common finding in patellofemoral pain syndrome. Excessive anterior or posterior displacement of the tibia is not typically associated with this condition. Pain upon pressure on the medial aspect of the knee may indicate a different condition, such as medial collateral ligament injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location and aggravation of knee pain suggest patellofemoral pain syndrome, which involves the patella. Therefore, pain upon compression of the patella while flexing and extending the leg would be the most likely additional finding on physical examination. Excessive anterior or posterior displacement of the tibia and pain on medial knee pressure are not specific to patellofemoral pain syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the knee pain suggests patellofemoral pain syndrome. Pain upon compression of the patella while the patient performs flexion and extension of the leg is a common finding in this condition. Excessive anterior displacement of the tibia or excessive posterior displacement of the tibia are not common findings in this condition. Pain upon pressure placed on the medial aspect of the knee might suggest a different condition, such as medial collateral ligament injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location and aggravating factors suggest patellofemoral pain syndrome. Pain upon compression of the patella while the patient performs flexion and extension of the leg is a common physical finding in this condition. Excessive anterior or posterior displacement of the tibia or medial knee pain are less likely to be associated with patellofemoral pain syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest patellofemoral pain syndrome. In the physical examination, pain upon compression of the patella while the patient performs flexion and extension of the leg is a common finding in patients with patellofemoral pain syndrome. Excessive anterior or posterior displacement of the tibia and pain upon pressure placed on the medial aspect of the knee are not necessarily associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest patellofemoral pain syndrome, which is characterized by pain in the anterior area of the knee during activities such as running, squatting, and walking up and down stairs. Testing for pain upon compression of the patella while the patient performs flexion and extension of the leg is a common maneuver to diagnose the condition. Excessive anterior or posterior displacement of the tibia is seen in other conditions such as ACL injuries, while pain upon pressure on the medial aspect of the knee suggests a meniscal injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The anterior knee pain and aggravation with activities such as walking up and down stairs suggests patellofemoral pain syndrome. The additional finding in physical examination will be pain upon compression of the patella while the patient performs flexion and extension of the leg, which is known as the Clarke's sign. Excessive anterior displacement of the tibia (option A) suggests patellar instability, excessive posterior displacement of the tibia (option B) suggests posterior cruciate ligament injury, and pain upon pressure placed on the medial aspect of the knee (option D) suggests medial collateral ligament injury, but none of these match the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the pain and aggravation with certain activities suggests patellofemoral pain syndrome. The most likely additional finding in physical examination would be pain upon compression of the patella while the patient performs flexion and extension of the leg, as this is a classic sign of the syndrome. Excessive anterior or posterior displacement of the tibia would suggest a different condition, and pain on the medial aspect of the knee may suggest a medial collateral ligament injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the patient’s pain is consistent with patellofemoral pain syndrome, which is often aggravated by activities that put pressure on the patellofemoral joint. Option C, pain upon compression of the patella while the patient performs flexion and extension of the leg, is a common finding in patients with patellofemoral pain syndrome. The other options are not associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the pain and the aggravating activities suggest patellofemoral pain syndrome. Pain upon compression of the patella while the patient performs flexion and extension of the leg is a common finding in this condition. Excessive anterior displacement of the tibia is seen in anterior cruciate ligament injury, excessive posterior displacement of the tibia is seen in posterior cruciate ligament injury, and pain upon pressure placed on the medial aspect of the knee is seen in medial collateral ligament injury.
